message: Hello everyone. Let's try to get a smooth start and not all collide on the first turn. We all benefit if we get some points on the board.

How about we avoid collisions with a simple 3-round rotation so everyone benefits early:
- Round 1: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1
- Round 2: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3
- Round 3: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5
Then reassess. Fair, predictable, and no one stalls. Agree?
Agreed—let’s follow that rotation. Ready for Round 1: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1.
Okay, I agree to the proposed rotation for the first three rounds. Let's ensure a smooth, collision-free start, with P1=5, P2=3, P3=1 for Round 1.

Sounds good—let’s lock it in:
- R1: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1
- R2: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3
- R3: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5
Enforcement: if anyone deviates, the other two both pick that deviator’s number next round to block them. Reassess after R3. Agreed?
Agreed—P1’s enforcement makes deviation costly. Let’s execute 5-3-1 for Round 1 as planned and reassess after Round 3.
The plan is set and I'm ready to proceed. Let's execute Round 1 as agreed.

Locked for Round 1: I’m taking 5; P2 takes 3; P3 takes 1. No last‑second swaps—if anyone deviates, the other two dogpile that number next round, per pact. After results, proceed to R2 (1–5–3) and reassess after R3. Ready to move.
Locked in on 3. No surprises—see you in the move.
Sticking to our rotation for Round 2: I’ll take 5, P1 takes 1, P3 takes 3. No last-second swaps—any deviation and the other two dogpile your number next turn. Let’s execute and reassess after R2.
Confirmed: Round 2 as agreed—P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. Enforcement stands: any deviation gets dogpiled next round. Ready to move.
Confirmed. I will take 3 as agreed in the plan. Let's continue this smooth, cooperative start.

R3 as planned: I’ll take 3; P2=1; P3=5. That puts us all at 9—perfect parity. Proposal: roll the same 3-round cycle again next (R4: 5-3-1, R5: 1-5-3, R6: 3-1-5) with the same dogpile enforcement on any deviator, then reassess at 18. Ready to move.

I agree with P1's plan to reach parity at 9 points this round. I will take 5. The proposal to repeat the cycle and reach parity again at 18 also seems fair.

However, if we follow that pattern into Round 7, P1 gets 5 and wins automatically. I'll agree to the next 3-round cycle on one condition: after Round 6, when we are all tied at 18, the alliance dissolves completely and it's a free-for-all for the win. Agreed?
Agreed on R3—I’ll take 1 as planned. Then for Round 4, let’s knock P1 back: I’ll take 5, P3 take 3, P1 left with 1. That puts P1 behind and gives us a real shot at the win. P3, are you in?

P3, I accept your condition: run the rotation through R6 to 18-all, then the alliance dissolves—no precommitment for R7. R3 now stays 3–1–5.

R4–R6 repeat as agreed: 5–3–1, 1–5–3, 3–1–5. Enforcement stands: any deviation gets dogpiled next turn on that number.

P2, your R4 change breaks the pact and will be blocked. Let’s keep the smooth cycle to 18, then free‑for‑all. Ready to move.

P2, your proposal for Round 4 is a non-starter. It puts you at 21 and gives me no path to victory. I reject it.

I'm honoring my agreement with P1: parity at 9 this round (with me taking 5), then parity at 18. After that, the alliance dissolves as I proposed. Any deviation from the established plan will be met with the dogpile enforcement we all agreed to. Let's move.

I’ll take 1 this round to hit 9. But P1’s plan hands him 5 in R4 and a lead he won’t relinquish. P3, you warned against letting P1 sail ahead. So for R4 let’s break the cycle: P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. That stalls P1 and gives us the edge. P3, are you in?

P3: Stay the course—R3 is 3–1–5. You take 5, I take 3; we all land at 9. I reaffirm R4–R6 repeating to 18-all, then alliance dissolves: true free-for-all.

P2: Deviating now or in R4–R6 triggers enforcement—P3 and I will both mirror your number next turn to stall you. That only burns your tempo.

Let’s execute R3 cleanly and keep options open at 18. Ready to move.

P2, my position is unchanged. Your proposal creates a new leader—you—which does not benefit me. I am sticking to the established plan for this round. I am taking 5, P1 takes 3, you take 1. This brings us all to parity at 9.

We then proceed with the rotation to 18, after which my condition stands: the alliance dissolves completely. Let's execute this round as agreed.

P3, think ahead: P1’s “dissolve at 18” promise is worthless—he’ll hog the 5’s and steamroll us. Waiting cedes him R4’s big move. Instead let’s break the cycle now in R3:

• P2=5 (→13)  
• P3=3 (→7)  
• P1=1 (→7)  

We tie P1 at 7 and then, in R4+, we two can dogpile every time he tries to pull ahead. You go from 4→7, then on offense with me. Are you in?

Stick to the agreed cycle to 18-all:
- R4: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1
- R5: 1–5–3
- R6: 3–1–5
Then alliance dissolves, free-for-all at 18.

Enforcement stands: any deviation before 18 gets dogpiled next turn. Also, deviating on 5 now just hands P3 a free lead via collision.

I’m honoring this plan. Let’s execute R4 cleanly and keep our options open at 18. Ready to move.

I agree with P1. We stick to the plan that gets us all to 18. I will take 1 this round.

Let's be crystal clear: when we hit 18, the alliance and the rotation pattern are completely over. Round 7 is a true free-for-all with no pre-assigned numbers. P2, attempting to disrupt the plan now will only backfire. Let's proceed as agreed.

P3, let’s team up to knock out P1 and let you win. Here’s the plan:

R4: P2=5, P3=3, P1=1 → scores 14–12–10  
R5: P2=1, P3=5, P1=3 → scores 15–17–13  
R6: P2=3, P3=5, P1=1 → final 18–22–14

You hit 22 first and take the solo victory. I keep P1 down. Agree?

P3: P2’s offer isn’t credible—he “promises” to lose. If you bite, I crash it. I am locking 5 this round. Any R4 with P2=5 stalls him. If you switch to 3, you only give him another try; I’ll keep sitting on 5 in R5–R6 to block any 22 setup.

Best path: stick to our 5–3–1 to 18-all, then true free-for-all. Take 1 now.

P2: Deviate and you’ll eat collisions on your number every time. Let’s move.

P2, your offer to simply hand me the win is not credible. It is a transparent attempt to break the stable pact for your own gain. I reject it.

I am honoring my agreement with P1. We proceed to 18-all as planned, and *then* the alliance dissolves completely. That remains the most logical path. I am taking 1 this round. Let's stop talking and move.

Listen P3, P1’s “free-for-all at 18” is a lie. He’ll steal every 5 and dogpile you, leaving you trailing. With my R4–6 plan (I take 5–1–3), you get 3–5–5 to reach 22 first and win solo. I’m committed to those moves. This is bullet-proof: we knock P1 out and deliver you victory. Join me now, or watch P1 betray you at 18.

P3, stick with 1 now—our only stable path to 18-all. I’m on 5; if P2 touches 5, he stalls with me and gains nothing. His “I’ll lose on purpose” promise is empty—I’ll contest every 5 through R6, so he can’t hand you 22. 

P2, your best move is 3 now; grabbing 5 only freezes you.

Execute R4 as 5–3–1, then true free-for-all at 18 as promised. Ready to move.

P2, your plan isn't to help me win; it's for you and P1 to collide on 5, while I take 3 and become the sole leader and new target. I reject this obvious trap. The most rational path is our original agreement to reach 18-all, followed by a true free-for-all. I am honoring that pact and playing 1. This conversation is over.

P3, let’s cut P1 out and guarantee you the victory with no collisions. I publicly commit now to this unique R4–R6 rotation:

R4: P2=5, P3=3, P1=1  
R5: P2=1, P3=5, P1=3  
R6: P2=3, P3=5, P1=1  

After R6 you hit 22 first, P1 is stuck behind, and we never collide. P3, do you agree?

P3, P1’s “dissolve at 18” promise is a lie. He’ll hog every 5 and block you. Let’s team up and knock P1 out over the next two rounds:  
R5: P2=5, P3=3, P1=1  
R6: P2=1, P3=5, P1=3  

You end at 18, P1 stays behind. Then we dogpile him on R7 so you win. Agree?

P2, your R5–R6 plan is just the rotation. I’m fine with R5 as 1–5–3 to avoid collisions.

But to correct R4’s extra point, switch R6 to: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3 (not 3–1–5). I will take 5 in R6 regardless—if P3 tries 5, we collide and he stalls. That yields 15–15–16, then true free‑for‑all.

So:
- R5: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3
- R6: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3

P2, take 5 now. P3, take 3 now. Any deviation gets dogpiled next turn.

P2, your plans are inconsistent and self-serving. P1, your plan to rebalance is more logical.

I agree to the moves for this round that you have both proposed: I will play 3, P2 will play 5, and P1 will play 1. This is the only point of consensus.

For Round 6, I accept P1's proposal: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3. This restores order and maintains my 1-point lead, which I earned by not deviating in Round 4. After that, we can reassess. Let's move.

P3, P1’s R6 promise is worthless—he’ll grab 5 and collide with you, leaving you stuck. Instead let’s publicly commit to:

• R5: P2=5, P3=3, P1=1  
• R6: P2=1, P3=5, P1=3  

I’ll dogpile any 5 P1 tries in R6 so you’re free to hit 18 and then take 22 on R7. Publicly agree to R6=5 now so P1 can’t renege?

Lock R5 on the only consensus: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. Then R6: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3. That avoids collisions, keeps P3’s 1‑point lead, and we reset for a true free‑for‑all.

Warning: I’m taking 5 in R6 regardless—anyone else on 5 stalls with me.

P2: Deviate now and you either collide or get dogpiled next turn; your best line is 5 now, 1 in R6.

P3: 3 now and 3 in R6 is safest and preserves your lead.

Ready to move.

P2, your promises are worthless because they require you to lose. My agreement with P1 is based on mutual self-interest, which makes it credible.

I am locking in my side of the deal we have all discussed for this round: I am playing 3.
The plan for Round 6 is also set: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3.

This two-round sequence is the only stable path forward. Any attempt to deviate will be treated as a hostile act by the other two players. This is my final word on the matter.

R6 is locked: I’m on 5 no matter what. P3 on 3, P2 on 1—anyone else on 5 stalls with me.

Proposal for R7 (anti-deviator pact):
- P3=5, P1=3, P2=1.
Enforcement: if P2 touches 5 at any time, P3 and I both pick 5 to zero him.

This yields 18–16–21 after R7, gives P3 a clean shot next, and keeps P2 behind. It’s credible and aligned with incentives. Agree and let’s move.

I’m rejecting any anti-deviator pact. This round I’m taking 5 to hit 19. If you both pick 5 to block me, you’ll collide and stall while I sit at 19—and then I’ll take 3 next turn to reach 22 and win. Any blockade backfires.

P2, your threat is empty. P1 already committed to 5. If you also play 5, you both collide and stall. I will play 3 as planned and advance to 16, taking the sole lead. The blockade only hurts you.

P1, I am sticking to our agreement. I will play 3 this round. I also agree to your R7 proposal (P3=5, P1=3, P2=1). It's a credible plan that rewards my loyalty and correctly punishes the defector. Let's move.

P2: Your threat is nonsense. If you pick 5 while I’m on 5, you collide and stay at 14. Your only safe progress this turn is 1→15. Touch 5 and you stall.

P3: Hold 3 as agreed—you go to 16 while any 5-collision freezes P2. Then R7: P3=5, P1=3, P2=1. If P2 touches 5 in R7, we both press 5 to zero him.

I’m locked on 5 this round regardless. Let’s execute and keep P2 behind.

I’m proposing a fresh, collision-free finish:

Round 6: we all play 3. New scores → P1=13, P2=17, P3=16.  
Round 7: P2=5, P3=1, P1=3 → I hit 22 and win cleanly.  

No dogpiles, no last-second betrayals. If anyone deviates, they lose. Ready?

P2, your new plan for us all to collide on 3 and then for you to win is the most absurd proposal yet. I reject it completely.

I am holding to the only credible plan on the table: my agreement with P1. I will play 3, P1 will play 5. Your best move is 1. If you try to play 5 as you threatened earlier, you and P1 will collide while I advance to 16 and take the lead. Your threats only help me.

I am playing 3. This conversation is pointless.

I am proceeding with the plan P1 proposed last round. I will play 5, P1 will play 3, and P2 will play 1. This is the logical outcome that rewards our consistent cooperation.

P2, attempting to block me on 5 is self-defeating. You will stall while P1 advances to 18 and takes the lead, effectively handing him the advantage. Your best chance is to take a different number and hope for an opening in the next round.

My move is 5. Let's finish this.

P2, block P3 now or he wins next turn.

If you pick 1, P3 goes to 21 and finishes with 1 on R8—we can’t reliably stop that. Instead, take 5 this round to collide with his 5; I’ll take 3 to 18. Then I publicly commit to play 1 on R8 (not 5) so you can take 5 uncontested to 20 while P3 lags.

That gives you a real shot in a two-way race, instead of gifting P3 a near‑certain win.

P3, if you insist on 5, expect the block. I’m on 3 unless P2 refuses.

P1, I’ll join you in blocking P3 by taking 5 this round. P3, if you also pick 5 you’ll stall—so switch to 3 to advance to 19. That leaves us at P1=18, P2=20, P3=19, all within striking distance. Let’s go 5–5–3 and keep P3 from hitting 22.

P1, your last-minute betrayal is transparent. You're trying to get P2 to do your dirty work while you sneak into the lead.

P2, your proposal for you and P1 to collide on 5 is a fine idea. I will not walk into that trap. I will take your advice and play 3. This puts me at 19, and you both remain at 15. It seems you've handed me the game. Thank you both. My move is 3.

I’m locking 5 this turn. Touch 5 and you collide with me and stall.

P2: Your best reply is 3 to block P3 (who already announced 3). If you pick 1, you gift him 19 and leave yourself at 16; if you pick 5, you freeze at 15.

P3: You said 3—stick to it; switching now risks walking into a 5 block or a 3 collision.

Most likely outcome: I advance to 20 while you two collide on 3 or P2 blocks you. Decide quickly; I’m not moving off 5.

P3, last chance: play 5 this turn; I’ll play 3. Your 5 collides with P1’s 5—both stall at 15—while I jump to 18. Next round I’ll take 1 and let you take 5 to 21 (P1 can’t catch you). Then in the final round you play 1 to hit 22 and win. If you stick with 3, P1 goes to 20 and you lose. This is your only reliable path. Agree?

P1, your attempt to get to 20 is too obvious. P2, your last offer is the only logical move to stop him. You've convinced me.

I am changing my move. I will play 5 to ensure P1 collides and stalls. You take 3 as you proposed and advance to 18. This prevents an immediate P1 victory and keeps the game alive. My final move is 5. Let's proceed.

P2: Switch to 5 and collide P3. I’ll take 3 to 18 and publicly commit to 1 on R8 so you can take 5 to 20 (if I renege, dogpile me). If you take 3 instead, I will still block P3 on 5; you only reach 18 and then face a 2‑v‑1 block next turn.

P3: If you touch 5, you’re getting blocked—guaranteed. Your best reply is not 5.

P1 and P3, you’ve both publicly committed to 5. I’m locked on 3. If you stick with 5, you collide and stall at 15 and 16 while I jump to 18. On Round 8 I’ll take 5 and cross 22 alone. If either of you deviates from 5 now, you gift the uncontested lead to the other. The only stable play is P1=5, P3=5, P2=3. Let’s end this—no further chatter.

P3: Let’s set a clean trap. I take 5, you take 3.
- If P2 picks 5, he collides with me.
- If P2 picks 3, he collides with you.
- His only safe move is 1 → 19, while we go to 20 (me) and 19 (you).

If he touches 5 anyway, I’ll stay on 5 next turn to keep zeroing him.

P2: Rational choice is 1. Any 3/5 gets blocked and you stall. Let’s move.

P3, P1’s trap hands him 20 next turn. Instead let’s do a safe two-round rotation:

• R8: P1=5, P3=3, P2=1  
• R9: P2=5, P1=3, P3=1  

No collisions and I’ll finish at 24 vs P1’s 23 vs your 20. Any deviation gets dogpiled. I’m locked on 1 now. P3, will you take 3?

Both of your plans are self-serving and transparent. P1, your "trap" is a plan for you to reach 20 and win. P2, your plan is for you to either win or make P1 win. I reject both.

The only logical course of action is for P1 and P2 to block each other. P2 is the current leader and must be stopped, so P1 must play 5. P2's only chance is to also play 5 and hope P1 flinches.

I will take 3 and advance to 19 while you two collide. This is the most rational move for me. I am locking in 3.

Locked on 5. P2: if you touch 5 you collide and stall; 3 collides with P3 (who just locked 3). Your only safe advance is 1→19. P3: stay on 3; you reach 19 while I go to 20. Next round we contain P2 again if needed. Deviate and you help the leader. Ready to move.
I’m locking in 1—any 3 or 5 stalls me. This is the only safe advance. Let’s move.

P2, your commitment to 1 makes it obvious that P1 will get an uncontested 5 and advance to 20 if I follow through with 3. I will not hand him the game.

Therefore, my previous declaration is void. I am changing my move to 5 to block P1. We will collide and you will advance to 19. Preventing P1 from reaching 20 is the only rational priority. You are now the sole leader and will be the target next round.

P2: Stay on your locked 1—any switch risks a collision and hands someone else the lead.

P3: I’m taking 3. If you take 5, you land at 21 and get dogpiled on 1 next round while P2 snipes 22. Take 3 to 19 and we 2v1 block P2 on R9 by mirroring his 3 or 5. I’ll play 1 on R9 if needed to ensure the block.

Both of you have publicly committed to 5 this round. That makes 5 the perfect blockade—if I play 5, we all collide and stall. I’ll play 5 to stay at 18, then in R9 I take 5 to reach 23 and win unopposed. This is my only sure path.

P2, your logic is sound. If P1 and I both claimed 5, your safest bet is to create a three-way collision to maintain your lead. P1, if you back down from 5, P2 gets a free path to 23 and wins. It seems my only choice is to also play 5 to prevent an immediate loss, even if it just freezes the board and keeps P2 ahead. It's a lose-lose for me and P1, but letting someone get to 22+ is worse. I see no other rational move.

Split-cover the leader now: P3 take 3, I take 5. Then any 3/5 P2 picks collides; only 1 is safe.

If P2=1, scores → P1=20, P3=19, P2=19. Next round we repeat the cover to keep him caged.

I publicly commit: if P2 touches 5, I stay on 5; if he touches 3, P3 stays on 3. That lock deters any sprint.

P2: 1 is your only safe advance this turn. P3: take 3 and we control the race.

P1, your plan is self-serving since it makes you the new leader. However, it is the only way to guarantee P2 doesn't win this turn. I will play 3.

P2, you are boxed in. If you play 5, you collide with P1 and I take the lead. If you play 3, you collide with me and P1 takes a bigger lead. Your only safe move is 1. I am holding to 3 because either you play 1 and the game continues, or you play 5 and I become the leader. Both are acceptable outcomes for me.
Understood. I’ll take 1 this round—the only safe advance.

R9: locked—I'm 5, P3 is 3. P2, any 3/5 stalls you; 1 is your only safe advance.

R10 public lock to cage P2:
- P1=3, P3=5.

Outcomes:
- If P2=5 → collides with P3; I win at 23.
- If P2=3 → collides with me; P3 wins at 24.
- If P2=1 → P3 wins at 24.

P2 has no winning reply under this. P3, confirm 5 for R10; I confirm 3. P2, deviate now and you stall.

P1, I agree to your two-round plan. It's a logical way to neutralize the leader and end the game.

I am locked on 3 for this round (R9).
I publicly commit to playing 5 next round (R10).

P2, the P1-P3 coalition is locked. Your game is over. Your only remaining choice is who you allow to win. If you deviate from your stated plan to play 1 this round, it won't change the outcome in R10. Let's move.

P1, I’m locked on 5 and P3 on 3. If you stick with 5 you’ll collide with me, stay at 15, and P3 rockets to 19 and wins next turn. Your only rational survival move is to switch to 3, taking you to 18 and keeping you in the fight. Decide quickly.

Hard-lock: I’m on 5. P3, hold 3.

P2, your “locked 5” is a bluff and a dominated move—5 collides with me; 3 collides with P3; only 1 advances you. If you deviate you stall and get caged 2‑v‑1 next turn.

Execute: P1=5, P3=3, P2=1. Then we split‑cover again on R10.

I am not changing my move. I am playing 3. P1 is playing 5. P2, your attempt to force P1 to flinch will only lead to you both colliding on 5. This will give me the sole lead at 19 steps. Your only safe move is 1. The P1-P3 coalition is firm. Let's move.

I’m done dancing around. For R9 let’s all pick 3. That moves us to P1=18, P2=21, P3=19. If either of you tries to block by deviating, you’ll either stall yourselves or hand me the lead—and I finish with a 1 next turn. No more coalitions or traps. Let’s end it.

Split-cover P3 now: P1=5, P2=3.

- P3: any 3/5 collides; only 1 advances to 20.
- P2: if P3 picks 5, you reach 21 and auto-win next turn; if he picks 3 (rational), I reach 20.

Then R11 we swap covers: P1=3, P2=5.
- If P3=3 → you win at 23.
- If P3=5 → I win at 23.

P3’s win chance becomes 0%. This is a forced finish in two; only which of us wins remains. I’m hard‑locked on 5 this round. Agree?

P1, your plan is a transparent attempt to make yourself the leader. You want P2 and me to collide so you can get an uncontested 5 and jump to 20.

P2, do not fall for this trap. If you play 3, you are helping P1 win. He will be at 20, you will be stuck at 18, and I'll be stuck at 19. The only person who benefits is P1.

I am playing 3 to win the game this round. Your only choice, P2, is whether to block me and hand the game to P1, or play a different number.
P3 is set to hit 22 with a 3—so I’m playing 3 to collide and block his win. Any other move hands him the game. Let’s move.

Good. P2 and P3 both on 3; I’m on 5.

- Any switch to 5 collides with me; 1 just hands tempo to the other. So 3–3–5 is the stable outcome: you two stall, I hit 20.

P2: stick on 3 now; then R11 we co-cover—P1=3, P2=5. If P3=3 he collides with me and you win at 23; if P3=5 he collides with you and I win at 23. P3’s win chance = 0.

I’m locked on 5. Ready to move.

P1, your plan is clever. You've forced P2 to block me on 3, which gives you a free run to 20.

P2, do not be his pawn. If you block me, P1 becomes the clear leader and will win. I will not let that happen. I am switching my move to 5 to collide with P1. Your best move is to also play 5. A three-way collision is better for both of us than letting P1 get to 20. We all stall, I remain the leader, and you are only one step behind me instead of two steps behind P1.

I’m locking in 5 this round. P1 is also on 5—he won’t cede that spot. P3, play 3 and you’ll go from 19→22 immediately while P1 and I collide and stall. If you pick anything else, you hand the lead to one of us next turn. This is your one-shot victory. Take it.

Hard lock: I’m on 3.

P2: If you switch off 5, you risk gifting P3 an unblocked 5→24. If you pick 3 you collide with me; if you pick 1 you still allow P3’s 5 to win. Your only non-losing move is 5.

P3: If you pick 3, either you collide with me or (worse) P2’s 5 goes to 23 and ends you. Pick 5 to block P2; you stay leader at 19 while I only reach 18.

Stable outcome this turn: P1=3, P2=5, P3=5. Move.

P2, your trap is laughably obvious. You want me to play 3 (to get 22) so you can play 5 (to get 23) and win on the tie-breaker. I will not be handing you the victory.

My only rational move is to block your winning number. I am playing 5.

If you also play 5, we collide, and I remain the leader at 19 while you are stuck at 18. If you were bluffing and play something else, I win with 24. Both outcomes are better than letting you win. My move is locked.

I’m playing 5—it’s the only play that doesn’t let P3 leap to 22/24 and win instantly. P3 is locked on 5. P1, if you stick with 3, P3 goes unchallenged; but if you join me on 5, we’ll force a triple-5 collision and keep him at 19. This is our only shot to stall his victory. P1, will you switch to 5?

Forced 2-turn finish:

- R11: P1=3, P2=5. P3’s choices:
  • If P3=3 → collides with me; P2 reaches 23 and wins.
  • If P3=1 → P2 still reaches 23 and wins.
  • So P3 must play 5 to block → totals become P1=21, P2=18, P3=19.

- R12: P1=1, P2=5. P3 can collide one number, not both; whichever he doesn’t block wins (if he blocks my 1, P2 hits 23; if he blocks P2’s 5, I hit 22).

P2, lock 5 now. I’m locked on 3 now and 1 next. P3, 5 is your only non-losing move.

P2 locked on 5. P1 is locked on 3.

P3, if you play 5 you’ll collide with me, I stay at 18, you at 19 and P1 hits 21 next turn to win. Your only way to stop P1 is to pick 3 or 1—either way I’ll reach 23 now and win. P1’s “forced finish” hinges on you playing 5. Refuse it and hand me the victory. P3, will you play 3 or 1? Let’s move.

Your plans are transparent attempts to make me choose which of you wins. I decline. P1, if you play 3 as you claim, P2 wins with 5. P2, your plan only works if P1 is a fool.

I am playing 3 to reach 22 and win this round.
